title: Mum claims daughter, 11, died because doctors took away painkillers
text:
Karina Driscoll doesn’t want her daughter Melody’s death to be in vain (Picture: Karina Driscoll)

A grieving mother embroiled in a bitter dispute with doctors over her 11-year-old daughter’s death is fighting for answers.

Melody Driscoll suffered excruciating pain before dying from a complex medical condition at Kings College Hospital in June last year.

In a bid to finally get closure, mum Karina, from Thornton Heath, south London, has set up an online fundraising page to hire a legal team for an upcoming inquest.

She says doctors’ decision to withdraw drugs used for pain relief triggered a pancreatitis which led to her ‘internally bleeding to death’.

Melody suffered from Rett Syndrome, a rare genetic disorder causing severe mental and physical defects.

Ed Sheeran visited Melody at Epsom Hospital in November 2016 (Picture: Karina Driscoll)

Karina is convinced Melody could still be here if she stayed on her medication (Picture: Karina Driscoll)

She suffered from regular organ inflammation and internal ruptures throughout her body, causing blood to flow out of her stoma and other orifices.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Karina, 37, told Metro.co.uk her symptoms were kept at bay by a combination of morphine, ketamine and steroids given to her while she was at Great Ormond Street Hospital.

She said: ‘It would, in the long term, shorten her life but it meant that she could come home and go to school.

‘We wanted her to come off these drugs but we wanted to do it right, we wanted to do it where she was still well.’

She even had the chance to meet Ed Sheeran a few times while she was in a better condition.

The parents accepted that TPN – a method of feeding fluids through connected tubes – could eventually lead to potentially fatal liver damage.

But they also recognised that it helped her and they wanted Melody to have a good quality of life for as long as possible.

Melody hugs and kisses her dad Nigel, 48 Melody’s mum said some doctors played down her excruciating pain

After transferring to Kings College Hospital in July 2017 to receive treatment from a specialist liver doctor, Melody’s family became entangled in a legal fight over her medication.

Karina claims doctors decided her painkillers were not needed and that Melody’s writhing around, screaming, and signalling to painful parts of the body was a ‘behavioural problem’.

She says she was even accused of fabricated or induced illness – a rare form of abuse where a parent or carer exaggerates or causes symptoms in their child.

Czech police throw stun grenades at England fans as 10 arrested in Prague

Since speaking out, Karina says she has been contacted by five other parents who claim they have had the same accusation.

Advertisement

Advertisement

King’s College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust denied the accusations.

Melody’s parents enlisted the help of Charles Da Silva, the lawyer who worked on the Charlie Gard case, to try and sue the hospital and resume their daughter’s medication.

In December 2017 Croydon Council social workers threatened to put the girl in care to stop Karina and dad Nigel, 48, ‘obstructing her care’.

The local authority dropped the case a month later and apologised, but they then applied in March 2018 for all medical decisions to go through the court.

Ed Sheeran paid tribute to Melody at her funeral

Melody was hooked up to a stoma bag and a number of tubes used to administer drugs

The parents gave up and accepted that they had no choice but to let Melody’s painkillers be gradually taken away.

Karina said: ‘She would have died alone with no one around who knew her. We were literally forced to, we had no other option.’

Woman found dead 15 minutes before man she knew is killed by train

‘Every time they lowered the medication, Melody’s symptoms would come back.’

She said doctor’s refusal to acknowledge how much the drugs helped her flew in the face of advice from staff at Great Ormond Street, Epsom Hospital, teachers and carers.

After suffering serious symptoms, Melody was rushed into intensive care with what doctors thought was a gallstone in her bile duct.

Karina says doctors then discovered signs of a pancreatitis and ended up perforating her bowel with a medical tube, causing severe bleeding.

Advertisement

The mother-of-six added: ‘I was telling them all along that this is what would happen if they took away her medication.’

Melody smiles at her mum during happier times

Her parents want an independent medical expert with no connection to any hospitals to back their corner at Melody’s inquest

Other surgeons were brought in for an emergency operation but they were unable to stop the bleeding from her pancreas.

Karina says one of the doctors told her the stone was not obstructing anything and would not have caused a pancreatitis so they left it inside.

Karina said: ‘They literally closed her up and told us she only had 24 hours to live. We were absolutely hysterical.’

But despite the odds, Melody kept on fighting for 11 more weeks until she eventually passed away.

Karina said: ‘She was in our arms when she died. There was blood everywhere, literally everywhere.’

‘Every time we close our eyes and go to sleep we see her bleeding in our arms.

‘I feel like it’s my fault, it’s my fault I let them take away the medication.’

Melody’s parents say there was ‘blood everywhere’ when she passed away in their arms

Karina says she wants to stop other children suffering in the same way her daughter did

With an inquest set for March next year, the family are now trying to raise £8,000 for a barrister and £3,000 for an independent medical expert with no connection to any hospitals.

Karina added: ‘I don’t want any other children to suffer like Melody did.

Advertisement

‘Melody’s life should not be in vain. It was like Melody’s life didn’t matter – and Melody mattered.’

A spokesperson for King’s College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust told Metro.co.uk: ‘We do not recognise the allegations made by Melody’s family.

‘While we recognise that this is difficult for Melody’s parents, all decisions taken with regards to her care were made by expert clinical teams as well as community-based services and in the best interests of the patient.’

Great Ormond Street Hospital said it would not be appropriate to comment at this time.
